column4: does anyone know how to install limewire on ubuntu, its really the only reason i installed it
try something better. Frostwire is on the Gnutella network and works very similarly, but better
sudo aptitude install frostwire
how do i install frostwire? do i download it or do i type that into terminal?
most things you can install from the repositories using aptitude or apt-get (apt-get and aptitude are essentially the same, but aptitude installs all dependencies on its own)
im sorry i just started using linux last night. is aptitude a program?
try "sudo aptitude install frostwire", and if your not ready for the command line interface "CLI", use synaptic package manager in system-->administration
i will try that, thanks so much!
aptitude is a "package manager" (no worries mate, this is my first month and the learning curve is amazing0
gotcha, i typed that into terminal but it said it was "unable to unlock administration directory"\

aptitude, apt-get, and synaptic aka synaptic package manager are the main ways to install, you wont have to worry about compiling from source or installing from downloads for a while, though if you find a .tar or .gz file that you want to install, you simply locate it by terminal and use the command install
so to do an installation from command line (terminal) you would type sudo aptitude install filename/program
you typed sudo aptitude install frostwire?
have you enabled all universe and multiverse repositories
i'm honestly not sure if i've enabled all repositories
go through the steps to do that first, its a big deal
ok i will do that right now
go to ubuntuguide.org and start trying the things it says, and youll start learning fast...though you will still not understand why they do it for a while....thats the fun of troubleshooting!
what is a root password?
it is your login password
i'm trying to install SunJava, and it won't work
there are two users in ubuntu to protect you, one that is your "user" account for running regular things, and a "superuser" or administrative account to edit configurations and main components
linux terminal is very case sensitive, make sure the package is named what it is, and all the letters are in proper case
